section.title: Nova-network: Create your first cloud network
section.para: These examples, using the nova-network API, walk you through the steps to create an isolated network, showing you how to access the Cloud Networks API through nova client commands or cURL commands so that you can quickly create isolated networks.

section.title: Create an isolated network
section.para: Before you create a server, you create an isolated network that you can attach to your new server.

To create an isolated network, you specify a name for your network and a Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR). A CIDR is a range of IP addresses used by a network. A CIDR address looks like a normal IP address except that it ends with a slash followed by a number. The number after the slash represents the number of addresses in the range. For more information, see
http://www.rackspace.com/knowledge_center/article/using-cidr-notation.

listitem.para: The isolated network must exist in the same region as the Cloud Server.
You can create up to three isolated networks with up to 64 servers attached to each one.
After you create an isolated network, you cannot rename it.

section.para:
For a full list of limitations, see the
Cloud Networks Release Notes (at http://docs.rackspace.com/servers/api/v2/cn-releasenotes/content/nova-boot.html).
After you create an isolated network, copy its network ID. You use this ID to attach the network to your server when you create your server.

section.title: Create an isolated network with the nova client
section.para: The following step shows you how to create an isolated network using the nova client.

procedure.title: To create an isolated network with the nova client

step.para:
Issue the following command:
$ nova network-create <network_label> <cidr>

listitem.para: network_label. The network label, such as my_new_network,
cidr. The IP block from which to allocate, such as 172.16.0.0/24 or 2001:DB8::/64.

step.para: The command returns the CIDR, ID, and label for the new network, as shown in the following output:
Copy the id value from the output. In this example, the id value is 1f84c238-b05a-4374-a0cb-aa6140032cd1, but use the value returned for your network.
You will use this value when you show network details or create a new server.

section.title: Create an isolated network with cURL
section.para: You can request a JSON or XML response when you issue a request in a cURL command.

procedure.title: To create an isolated network and request a JSON response

step.para:
Issue the following cURL command:
$ curl -s https://dfw.servers.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2/$account/&cnresource2; \ -X POST \ -H "X-Auth-Project-Id: $account" \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -H "Accept: application/json" \ -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" \ -d '{"network": {"cidr": "192.168.0.0/24", "label": "superprivate"}}' | python -m json.tool
In this cURL command, you specify several options. For information about options, see Table 2, “cURL Command-Line Options”.
The response returns the CIDR, ID, and label for the isolated network, as shown in the following JSON response:
Copy the id value from the output. In this example, the id value is 1f84c238-b05a-4374-a0cb-aa6140032cd1, but use the value returned for your network.
You will use this value when you show network details or create a new server.

procedure.title: To create an isolated network and request a XML response

step.para:
Issue the following cURL command:
$ curl -i https://dfw.servers.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2/$account/os-networksv2.xml \ -X POST -H "X-Auth-Project-Id: $account" -H "Content-Type: application/xml" \ -H "Accept: application/xml" \ -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" \ -d '<network cidr="192.168.0.0/24" label="superprivate_xml" />'
The response returns the CIDR, ID, and label for the isolated network, as shown in the following XML response:
Copy the id value from the output. In this example, the id value is 1f84c238-b05a-4374-a0cb-aa6140032cd1, but use the value returned for your network.
You will use this value when you show network details or create a new server.

section.title: List networks
section.para: After you create an isolated network, list networks to make sure it is listed along with the Rackspace networks.
For information about the Rackspace networks, see “Limitations of detaching from Rackspace networks”.

section.title: List networks with the nova client
section.para: The following step shows you how to list networks using the nova client.

procedure.title: To list networks with the nova client

step.para:
Issue the following nova client command:
$ nova network-list
For each network, the command returns the network ID, label, and CIDR, as shown in the following output:
In the network list, ServiceNet is labeled as private, and PublicNet is labeled as public.

section.title: List networks with cURL
section.para: You can request a JSON or XML response when you issue a request in a cURL command.

procedure.title: To list networks and request a JSON response

step.para: Issue the following cURL command: $ curl https://dfw.servers.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2/$account/&cnresource2; \ -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" | python -m json.tool Output:
For each isolated network, the response returns the CIDR. Additionally, for isolated networks and Rackspace networks, the response returns the network ID and label.

procedure.title: To list networks and request a XML response

step.para: Issue the following cURL command: $ curl https://dfw.servers.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2/$account/&cnresource2;.xml \ -H "Content-Type: application/xml" \ -H "Accept: application/xml" \ -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" Output:
For each isolated network, the response returns the CIDR. Additionally, for isolated networks and Rackspace networks, the response returns the network ID and label.

section.title: Show network details
section.para: You can show details for a specified network ID to confirm that the details are what you expect.

The response body returns the following fields: Show network response fields
Name Description
cidr The CIDR for an isolated private network.
id The network ID.
label
The name of the network.

section.title: Show network details with the nova client
section.para: The following step shows you how to show network details using the nova client.

procedure.title: To show information for a specified network ID

$ nova network <id>
